Bottle. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Aroma is chocolate, bourbon and brandy. Taste is chocolate, marshmallow, charred malt, caramel, bourbon barrel and boozy brandy. Incredible alcoholic heat that doesn't take away from the flavor. Palate is perfect. Thick, viscous and rounded. Not flat like some batches apparently have been. Really awesome. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black with small tan head.  Rich, malty, chocolate, boozy nose, with hints of vanilla and licorice.  Tastes very much like its two parts, the bourbon and brandy very prevalent. So so rich, malty with super thick and delicious goodness.  One of my favorite beers I have had, truly awesome
Deep black in color... Aroma of licorice, roasted malts... Flavor is smoky, notes of vanilla, licorice, and oak.... Rich roasted malts... Intensely good...

Had on tap at Deep Ellum, Allston, 1:30 pm. To tulip it pours a crimson reddish charcoal with a trim, sudsy mocha/khaki combination half a pinky in length. Smells delicately of Vermont maple syrup, organic soil, caraway seeds, raspberry preserve, roasted malts, char, chocolate almond milk, marshmallow root, oak, booze, and brown sugar, incredibly complex. Tastes of browned and kilned malts, leather, raisin bread, and roast. Wood, London yeast, sourdough, and black truffles by swallow. Heat is detected almost immediately. Keywords here: syrupy, thick and insanely smooth.

12.7oz bottle, shared by Dan. 2011 vintage. Black color. Minimal khaki head. Little dots of lace. Nice vanilla and wood in the nose. Light dark chocolate syrup. Wow, its good. Great big body. Smooth and chewy. Light carbonation. Some warmth, but no burn or bite. Very well-blended, and welcome, even. Good roast coffee, wood notes from the barrels, hints of apple. Awesome roasty aftertaste, nice bit of warmth and good vanilla in there. Very tasty one to savor.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2013 Amazing brandy and bourbon aromas predominate with a bit of coffee. Completely black syrup appearance/consistency, not much head to be seen.  Taste is a well rounded blend of bourbon, brandy, chocolate and dark fruits. Tastes more like a liquor than a beer. Mouthfeel is very thick, minimal carbonation. An amazing beer.
12.7 oz bottle purchased from Beercraft. Pouts a very dark brown and sticks to the glass. Very smooth for such a strong beer. One of my favorites.

From a 12.5 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of raisins, dark fruits and oak.  Viscous mouthfeel with slight carbonation.  Deep rich flavors of plums, dark cherries and raisins.  Smooth boozy finish.

On draft at the Cloverleaf. Pours thick and black with almost no head. The aroma is full of sweet raisins, milk chocolate, caramel, toffee, and subtle roasted woods. On the palate there is some thick sweetness that immediately contrasted by the mild bitterness of stone fruit cores and some roasty astringency. Great balance. Very tasty.

Bottle into a snifter. Pours deep brown with small tan ring, mostly still. Aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel, toffee, chocolate, and dark fruits. Taste is quite sweet and mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Very tasty.

Bottle into glass.  Pours dark brown with no head.  Complex aroma, with bourbon, vanilla, toffee, caramel, chocolate.  Taste follows and is very smooth and sweet.  Great mouthfeel.  Expensive but fantastic.
UPDATED: APR 22, 2013 Pours black with medium brown head. Some lacing. Aroma is of malt, alcohol, roasted malt, vanilla, super chocolate!

375 ml. bottle.  Thanks Tom!  Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, bourbon, chocolate, and vanilla.  Taste is bourbon, oak, vanilla, malt, dark fruit, chocolate, and coffee.  Wild, big, complex, and delicious!

Bottle 375ml.
Pours black with medium brown head. Some lacing. Aroma is of malt, alcohol, roasted malt, vanilla, chocolate. Taste is of malt, chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, lots of alcohol. Palate: Full bodied. Overall: Very good. Alcohol a bit dirty, maybe I would not drink more than a glass of this (per night).

Bottle (375 ml). Traded by pandableh, thanks Daniel! Black with a small diminishing beige head and barely no lacing. Aroma is rich and is of bourbon, chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla and caramel. Taste is about the same. Mouthfeel is creamy and sirupy. Full bodied. Low carbonation but no flat. This beer is extremely rich and complex. Nice sipper!

Deliverance in reverse, brandy serpent stout with bourbon angels share, thank you Monks. Pour unclear black coffee with almost no head. Aroma brings roasted chocolate, butterscotch, and lightly sweet liqueur notes. Flavor is so complex bringing roasted sweet malts, boozy smooth sweetness, ans even some light smoky brandy.

Black with a thin tan head. Great aroma full of roasted barley, vanilla, and toasted marshmallows. Roast coffee and bittersweet cocoa. Sweet vanilla, oak and light bourbon notes. Very nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, vintage 2011. Opaque dark brown with no head. Aroma is sweet rum, molasses, bourbon vanilla, dark dried fruit, roasted malt, cigar, coconut, alcohol. Taste is heavy sweet with some dark chocolate bitterness and salty liqourice. Full body, thick oily texture, soft carbonation. Spicy finish with a nice alcohol burn.

Bottle Vintage 2011. Pours opaque dark brown with light brown head. Aroma is heavy with sweet caramel, toffee, dark fruit, cigar, dark chocolate, vanilla, coconut, booze, oak, lactic, spice and a fatty note. Taste is heavy sweet and bitter, light tart. Body is medium+, texture is thick oily, carbonation is soft. Finishes roasted woody and very alcoholic hot and spicy.

A temperamental balance of alcoholic heat and sumptuous indulgent flavor.  Aromas of Marsala, vanilla, tawny port and brown sugar bread pudding.  The flavors are slightly leaning toward the barley wine side but dominated by the barrel notes of coffee infused tequila and a medicinal cough syrup flavor but with great vanilla.  The lack of heft here leaves me wanting more substance to match the intense presentation of flavors and aromas but it also makes everything about the beer more approachable.  Great beer, great blend that I would like to be in the room to witness.  Thank you lost abbey.  2012 bottle.
Delicous brew, nice harmony of both the brandy and bourbon along with rich chocolate dessert notes.

Bottle. Black pour with no head. Looks quite flat. Nose is heavy on the bourbon. Touch of spice comes through which resembles light brandy. Some smoke and dark chocolate in there. Dark fruits and heavy bourbon notes in the taste. Bitter and grainy spices, touch of vanilla. Quite bitter sweet with no carbonation. Too flat for my liking. Ok but thats it
little head, very dark, lots of fruit and alcohol notes. A wonderful beer!

375 ml bottle shared by jsprime. deep brown tan head well carbonated. both barrels are noticeable but not overbearing. the beer beneath the barrel is malty semi sweet and brown. medium bodied. quite good.

Tap. Murky chocolate colored, no head. Aroma: sweet oak, chocolate, dark fruit. Fantastic. Taste: sweet and cholatey. Palate: full thick syrupy body, moderate carb. Warming alcohol just right. Really great. Overall: one of my favorites.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375mL bottle from Beer Revolution last year. 2012 vintage. 

A: Fizzing pour settles down with a brown mocha head. Lifting bubbles throughout. Perfectly opaque black. Clings to the glass with tiny hands.

N: Deep penetrating oak. Hints of cherry and brandy, vanilla, caramel, and bourbon. Resonant chocolate and hints of espresso. So much caramel goodness. Molasses and more vanilla. Delicious. I can smell the alcohol, though. 

T: Chocolate, coffee, and some oak. Has a pronounced tannic quality. Molasses and vanilla in smaller qualities. Theres more bitterness than I would have expected from the nose. Raisins and prunes. Lots of brandy. This becomes unpleasant and astringent after awhile.

M: Creamy and expansive. Lots of and lots and lots of alcohol. 

O: Based on the nose, I thought this was going to nail down a top ten score. Thus, its a massive letdown, and probably not really recommendable given the high price. I remember liking the first vintage a lot more. Ill have to do a side by side, eventually.

Tiny expensive bottle.  Pours a full ruby/brown that shows minimal light qne not much of any head.  Smell is full on bourbon/brandy with a liquorer sweetness. Raisins, alcohol, vanilla, chocolate.  Intense.  Taste is much the same, but unlike some big noses, this one actually delivers.  Full on assault and perfect mixture of the brandy and bourbon aging.  Fantastic.  But too damn expensive.  Think I paid 13.99 for the tiny bottle.  Great, yes.  Worth it, maybe just once.

[4732-20120818] 12.7floz bottle. Roasted light sweet oakwood aroma. Brown black body with a quick foamy tan head. Sweet toasted bread soaked in honey flavour. Full boozy body. Nice sweet after notes. (8/3/8/4/16) 3.9
(@ Campground Brewdown 2012, Millmont, PA)

19th March 2011Opaque black beer, no real head. Semi dry palate, a little bit of carbonation. Dark malt and dark chocolate. Dry wood, pinch of vanilla. Booze comes in towards the finish - bourbon and a little brandy. Carbonated bite at the end. Nice beer but was expecting something more sumptuous.

Pours a dark brown almost little little to no head or lacing.  Smells of alcohol, cherries and bourbon. Tastes of chocolate, alcohol, brandy, bourbon. A really nice winter beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

First of all, I have to say Port Brewing/Lost Abbey is rapidly becoming my favorite brewery. Theres such a quality to all their brews, and I love the distinct flavor of their hoppy vs sweeter styles. That said, this is another stellar beer from them. Pours next to black with low tan head. Aroma is sweet, with raisin, figs, vanilla, hints of port and brandy and chocolate. Theres surprisingly little alcohol there. Taste has a very slight bitterness initially, before the sweet tones take over, and its not just one type of sweet but rather a complex mix of alcohol, dark fruit, vanilla and chocolate sweetness. Finish is long and very warming, with distinct brandy barrel (Id have said port if not for the Angels Share), perhaps a bit too overbearing. Body is full and creamy with somewhat present carbonation.

12.7 ounce bottle courtesy of pantanap. Thanks! Opened to celebrate a recent victory for a friend and his family. Pours a dark brown color with nearly no head. Weird aroma... roasted malts, cheese, whisky, chocolate, tart fruit finish. The taste is chocolate, roasted malts, toffee, whisky and a tart cherry finish. Medium bodied.

bottle at home ... thank Sev... dark black ... thin tan head ... soft coffee ... deep raisins .. soft bourbon nose ... dark roast ... berry fruit ... big bourbon front ... rich raisins ... rich roast fruits ... dark malts ... big bourbon ...

Bottle thanks Sev. Black with tan head. The aroma is insane, treacle, bourbon, oak, dark fruits fig and dates. Taste is huge, molasses, treacle, oak, bourbon, oak, fruitiness.  Thick and sweet. Incredible stuff.

Thanks Sev for this bottle. Pours a very dark brown colour with a fair, light tan head. Aroma of marzipan, bourbon, coconut, brandy, chocolate, honey, vanilla, caramel and oak. Similar flavours with mild carbonation, light CO2 prickle and an oily mouth-feel. This beer is truly phenomenal! Definite Pannepot notes. Wow!

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on December 7th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a black opaque with light white head. 
Aroma: Aroma of dark fruit and chocolate. 
Taste: Dark fruit, chocolate, faint roast, little bitterness.   
Palate:Medium body, slick.
Summary: Really glad I got to taste try this. Taste is really just well made, my descriptions probably dont do it justice.

Absolutely fantastic, 2011 bottle.  Pours like black oil, light head.  Smell is dark fruit, leather, chocolate, anise, brandy.Taste is big and sweet, and fruity with a long and lingering boozy finish.  However, its not hot, its a great flavor and well balanced.  So much going on, sip at 55 degrees or so.

Bottle. I had a hankering for a hearty dark sweet beer, so I grabbed this from my cellar, even though I tend to wait and share these bigger beers with one or two other people. Im glad I kept this one to myself, because it was amazing. The pour was pretty standard: dark brown with a low brown head that floated its way to the end, never vanishing completely. Aroma was mouthwatering. with lots of chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, and a bit of toasted coconut. Really delicious flavours that prominently displayed the barrel character; lots of oaky vanilla, sweet boozy bourbon, woody accents. But the base beer complemented and supported the barrel character easily, and the combination of generous rich dark malts with the brandy and bourbon was among the best Ive had. This beer demonstrates how barrel-aging can truly be something special. Outstanding.

text:
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2013 2011 vintage on draft at Devils Den Philadelphia. Pours ink black with a creamy beige head with impressive retention. Not getting a ton from the nose except hints of cocoa and espresso. The taste is out of this world. Just a beautiful combo of dark chocolate, coffee, bourbon that coat the tongue in silky smootheness. Almost perfect for me. Update: I have 5 bottles that I bought for $17 a piece. All infected! No excuse, Ill never buy one again.

Ok, update #2: LA sent me a care package with Deliverance thats not infected. Its spot on. When this beer is as intended, its fantastic. When its infected its a drain pour.

Trade from Anker, thanks buddy. Pours dark brown with a medium brown head. Aroma is alcohol, dark fruits, chocolate notes, tobacco notes. Flavor is roasted malt, burnt caramel, dark fruit, chocolate, light alcohol. Nice.

Refrigerated 12.7 oz. brown bottle corked and capped acquired through trade poured into a snifter.  Pours opaque black with small light brown head.  Little lacing, thick body, velvety texture, low carbonation, and brandy aroma.  Taste is dark fruit (mostly raisin), roasted salty malt, brandy, bourbon, oak, and a hint of alcohol.  Complex, alcohol is well covered for 12.5% abv, would be interested in having this again.

375ml bottle from Hop City, Atlanta. Shared at an autumn feast with a bunch of pals, and we all found the dark sludgy brew to be a potent dessert beer. Strong brandy and chocolate in the nose, really the Serpents that seems to hold it together, with the AS riding shotgun (this is all to the good, to me). The result is that the beer comes across very much like figgy pudding. Under the right circumstances, its aces.

On tap @ Bottleworks. Pours dark brown with a reddish tint. Thin creamy mocha head that laces well. Aroma is big syrupy sweet and boozy. Notes of brandy, port, licorice - no stout to speak of so far. Taste is similar though the boozy barrel aged flavors are mostly up front balanced by rich chocolate malts on the back. Perfect balance in the finish. Opens as it warms, oak, leather, earthy notes are present.  Clearly strong but you dont notice the 12.5%. Pretty much what youd expect from blending Serpents Stout and Angels Share, with the best qualities of both. Outstanding. Bonus points for the 6oz pour, you dont need much more than that.

Pours a dark and hazy, almost black with little head. Great aromas. The characteristics of the bourbon and brandy barrels are both apparent, along with a pretty complex malt bill. This makes for an excellent sipper.

Vintage 2011.
Appearance: The body is a nice pitch black with no head, rather a very thin and clean brown ring.
Aroma: The aroma is strong of oak with brandy and bourbon, on a second smell I pick up some chocolate and dark fruit notes. This is complex and begs to be dissected.
Taste: Whoa this is very complex, right away the fruits and thick syrupy chocolate intertwine while some brandy is noted, though mostly on the finish. The mid-taste is malty with only light hints of oak near the finish, with a mild burn of alcohol on the finish.
Palate: Thick and syrupy with just a light tingle.
Overall: This is an excellent sipping beer that has amazing complexity to it that begs to be drank slow. This is similar to sipping a fine cognac, enjoy slowly.

Bottle. Muddied brown pour, flat with minuscule head. Big aroma of  bourbon/brandy, chocolate, tootsie roll. . Crazy flavor profile, pretty much what aroma leads you into. Fuller mouthfeel. Delicious stuff

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2013 375ml at Jerrys. Black with slender brown head, but barrel-aged / Rich, complex, nose of coffee, tobacco, chocolate, dark fruit, bourbon barrel / Full body, smooth, deep, and mellow, sweet but not cloying, with some dryness in the middle, great balance and long finish with almost no heat / Rich, deep, flavors of semisweet chocolate, tobacco, roast coffee, toffee, licorice, date, fig, coconut, and bourbon barrel/ Awesome.  If the abbey brewed this, Id consider taking vows.

2011 bottle.
Almost black with a brown tinge, small brown head.
Aroma is great: toffee, chocolate, licorice, some bourbon, a bit boozy.
Taste: salty licorice, red berries, tart and vinous, wood, toffee, a hint of bourbon, chocolate, red wine.
Medium bodied with the astringency of a red wine.
Good, but not really what I was hoping for.  Would have liked it more without the vinous characteristics.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2013 Bottle shared by bvery, thanks dude! Dark with some head. Aroma and taste as expected, just a delicious mix of an imperial stout and barleywine (my two favorite styles) with the yummy bourbon.

Had this again March 23, 2013 - had a fresh 2013 bottle and this was still amazing.  Nice blend of chocolate, caramel and bourbon / brandy.  No change to ratings.

Bottle at Darkness Day 2012 - brought this home from Philly. Very dark pour. Im drinking this too cold. Aroma and taste of chocolate, fig, wood, and bourbon. Very good.

Rerated via a second bottle at Darkness Day 2012 - this one is a bit warmer. Unbelievable. The aroma and flavor really explode when it warmed up a bit.

375mL bottle, caged & corked.  Enjoyed in a single Sinners stem glass.   Black pour, light brown foam.  Carob aroma,  sweet malt, loads of chocolate aromas, caramel, bourbon oak barrel, charcoal, and alcohol.  Already, I sense this beer is worth every penny, ($19.99 to be exact).   Flavor of sweet roasted malts, burnt malt, charred sugars, dark fruits, alcohol burn, dark chocolate, raw date sugar, caramel notes, fudge, vanilla bean, roast, dark fruit bitterness.  Big Boy Daddy Candy!! Can taste the barrel aging.   Finishes with a good amount of heat.  Overall, it carries a Sweet Stout character, only much bigger.  Very very sticky texture.  Oily body, heavy, super strong. Loads of residual sugars. Sweet all through the finish.  A big One Hitter.

Wow, what an Aphrodisiac! 
 (Rating 3500!)

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2012 19.99 Bottle ordered from internet. Pours a light molasses with a fizzy headless head. Big aromas of the brandy, raisin, hints of fig, and some brown sugar. In the flavor the brandy comes through a little strong almost overpowering the other flavors. The alcohol is decently hidden on the palate but noticed a little throught the nose. Other undertoned flavors of brown sugar, caramel, and fig. Light sweetness with a medium bitter aftertaste. Cant say I enjoyed this to much as I really dislike the taste of brandy. Its much like drinking a light flavored brandy with some other flavors behind.

375 ml bottle served in a snifter at Local Option. 2010 vintage split three ways.

A: Pours a dark black with opaque brown edges. No head forms on the pour, only a thin brown ring. Solid stick is left on the glass, but the carbonation is low.

S: The bourbon is more pronounced than the brandy, but it is still well integrated in a nice chocolate brownie and vanilla. There is a nice boozy prune and dark fruit smell that gets balanced by a nice roasted malt.

T: The taste is much more decadent. Fudgey brownie, figs, light bourbon, sweet vanilla and caramel with a touch of oak. The toasted malts are great. The finish is a meaty umami flavor just bordering on a mild soy sauce, but it really rounds it in a robust way.

M: Low carbonation with a heavy body. Sticky and coating with a nice viscosity. There is a slight warming on the backend, but it plays nicely.

O: Delicious. Decadent, rich and very complex. I really enjoyed the different layers of flavors. I havent had this fresh, but at two years its drinking remarkably right now.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-25-2012

Ive acquired two bottles of this beer, both of which are gone now.  I held on to them for special occasions and to share with friends.  To those two people that sent me a bottle, thank you!  I shared one of them at a tasting at Belmont and it was one of the top beers of the night.  
 
This is my favorite Lost Abbey brew so far.  Super rich, full of a thousand flavors, thick, viscous, and overall a well-crafted and complex beer.  Yes, its nearly completely flat with no carbonation, but that actually works well with this beer as it is extremely full bodied.  Excellent beer!

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2013 Bottle at Stockholm Beer and Whiskey Festival 2012. Deep brown liquid with small to medium tan head. Aroma of raw sugar, chocolate, vanilla, coconut, wood, caramel and biscuit. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of raw sugar and caramel. Too sweet for my taste. Full bodied with low carbonation. Some booze as well.

FC Nordsjælland vs. Chelsea FC Champions League football night tasting in Odense, October 2012. Black with a lasting tan head. Big boozy aroma of bourbon and vineous dried fruitwith some licorice, molasses and vanilla. Sweet malty flavour with a roasted note, complex vineous alcohol and fruit. Mix two good things and they dont necessarily get better...

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, Oktober 2012. Pours dark brown nearly black with a small creamy head and lacings. Nose is wood, bourbon, vanilla and roast. Smooth and really vinous. Tasty.. Oak, vanilla and subdued coffee. Fine stuff..

Dark brown, opaque pour.  Sweet raisin/plum aroma.  Raisin/prune flavors.  Medium viscosity.  Very little carbonation. 

I like what Im getting here, but it would be improved with more carbonation to lighten/brighten it up a bit!

Thanks Chuck!  The beer pours to a black brown body with a tan head.  The aroma is amazing!  Rich chocolate with lots of bourbon, oak, brandy, malt, and caramel.  Flavors of chocolate bourbon and oak.  Sweet oats.  Light char.  Light syrup.  Rich coating mouthfeel.  Full body and delicious.  A winner!

375ML bottle pours pitch black.  Little to no carbonation and a little bit could go a long way here.  Medium bodied yet sweet, sticky, and syrupy.   The flavor profile is excellent with some chocolate, vanilla, and dark fruits but theres a fairly big whiskey presence too.  It has some good qualities but doesnt pull it together well and not worth hefty price for such a tiny bottle.

Pours like midnight, no head whatsoever (even with me trying to force it). an outsanding example of a barrel aged ale. Sip and enjoy . .  and enjoy. doesnt get much better than this, but i think i enjoyed Angels share a little more than this one.

Bottle @ home...vintage ´11 .... It pours pitch black with a small tan head head....The aroma is roasted malts, bourbon notes and dark fruits......The flavor is very nicely  dark fruits, bourbon, wood, dark roasted malt with a very nice warming alcohol finish....... love this! ..... would love to try this again when it have aged some years and one decade.... I believe it will be awesome then ! .....

Bottle.

Dark pour as one would expect given the formulation, with light carbonation that is spot on. Prominent brandy in the aroma, very clear Angels Share presence, vanilla, burnt sugar. Intensely sweet but somehow tolerably so. Just the right thing for sipping this evening.

Dark brown pour small tan head some lacing, clearly not a well carbonated beer.  Smells good, vanilla and oak first parts, clearly has some alcohol notes, some clear bourbon notes, after a little heat I get a touch of chocolate, nicely complex and mixed.  Big rich full palate, a bit syrupy very thick.  Flavor is sweet, complexly blended, hot alcohol in the swallows, lots of syrupy sweetness, maple syrup, bourbon, vanilla, then some of the serpent stout starts to show through with some roast malts, a touch of raisens.  Very delicious, but so sweet Im glad I shared the bottle with a friend.
Bottiglia condivisa da Marco, è stata unaltra grande delusione, una birra che è impossibile decifrare e che ti rimane in gola come un macigno. Bocciata senza appello

Pitch black body.  Minimal khaki head.  Streaky lacing.  Nose is a burst of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, and roast.  Flavor is similar with an assertive, but not domineering bourbon character taking over.  Sufficient malt base to mellow the sweetness of the bourbon.  Full bodied, slightly thing, semi-sweet but not cloying, mild alcohol warmth considering the ABV.
Draft at Flannys. Pours jet black with a tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, molasses and figs. Taste of smooth chocolate, lovely hot booze and roasted fig. Very silky mouthfeel. Freaking awesome.

Solid black with a healthy beige head. Thick aroma of vanilla, apple, oak and brandy. Off the chart complexity in the palate. Starts off with a nice apple brandy flavor followed by toffee and raisins with the warmth of a bourbon infused roasted malt at the finish.

Bottle, Brill Privatimport.
Big malty and milk chcolate aroma.
Complex and warming taste of dark fruits, chcolate and licorice.
Balanced heavy but yet drinkable.

Bottle. Pours black small beige head. Vanilla, milkchocolate, berry, and something a bit salt - roasted popcorn? Choclaty, vinous, nicley alcoholic. Warming. Actually quite balanced, and not as extreme as one would think.

2012-08-18. Very dark brown body nice tan head. 4+ Sweet bourbony aroma, vanilla over dark malt and something I cant place. Dark fruit notes. 7+ Flavour is rich, sweet dark malt, sweet bourbon vanilla, rich sweet dark malt core. Vanilla lingers in the finish and aftertaste. 7+ Smooth medium to full bodied palate. Bit simple, but richly delicious and enjoyable. Bottle, Campground Brewdown 2012

Bottle provided by Hopscotch. Thanks! The beer pours almost black with a small beige head. The aroma is vanilla, dark ripe fruit, wood, sweet roasted malt and some booze. The flavour is wood, liquorice, chocolate, dried dark fruit, vanilla, booze and sweet roasted malt. The stout is more profound than the barley wine imo. Heavy stuff.

Bottle I got in trade with Michael-Pollack) Thanks a bunch Michael!...Pour is dark black with a nice fluffy tan head..Nose is oak,caramel, coffee, sweet chocolate, bourbon and brandy, brown sugar,vanilla cake frosting..Taste is Oak, chocolate,brandy, glazed donuts, caramel, butterscotch, bourbon, alcohol..Very nice carbonation, palate is sweet and oaky

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2013 375ml bottle @ vPBF

Pours dark brown with a sticky light brown head.
Aroma of sweet molasses, bourbon, oak, vanilla, roasted malts, syrup and hints of coffee.
Taste is sweet and sugary with bourbon, oak, vanilla, molasses, syrup, chocolate and coffee.
Finish is sweetish and malty with oaky vanilla notes and syrup. Too sweet for my taste, but still quite tasty and complex ale. 8-4-8-4-16 = 4.0

Re-rated on 22.11.2013. This bottle is not as overly sweet as the one I had before. A very complex and balanced mix of a stout and a barley wine. Nice and enjoyable slow sipper.

Bottled 375ml (vPBF)
Dark opaque brown color, small beige head. Milky, vanilla aroma, not very strong. Medium-bodied, smooth palate. Vanilla, brandy appleness, roasted maltyness. Some alcohol in the finish. Nice and balanced, maybe lacks a bit depth (yes, I just had BA Speedway Stout before this).

375 ml bottle @ vPBF.
Pours deep ruby red color with small head. Aroma of bourbon, dark chocolate, sour fruits and mild dark toasted malts. Flavor of dark toasted malts, green apples, wooden notes, dark chocolate, bourbon and vanilla. Mild sourish palate with bitter malty finish. Very good but hoped for something more.
4426

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2012 
37,5 cl bottle @ vPBF, no BBE or vintage info
Aroma sweet and a bit light with raisins and plums. Flavour is sweet with raisins, some alcohol notes, licorice and apple lemonade. Very good, the sweetness does not disturb here much.

375 ml bottle @ vPBF 2012.
Pours a dark brown colour with a creamy beigeish head. Aroma of strong plums, bready malts and some alcohol. Flavour is quite sweet with syrup, bready malts, plums, oak and very interesting Calvados-like tingling green appleness. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a warming, dark fruity finish with dry oakiness. A dessert.

Aroma is nutty, some liquorice, sweet malts and some slight old ale like notes. Flavour is toffee, alcohol, ripe fruits, mild alcohol and some slight resiny notes.

Backlog purge. Bottle poured into a snifter. Dark dark brown with a lasting tan head. Luscious aroma with sweet chocolate and vanilla and an undercurrent of spicy bourbon. Flavor is fudge and toasted oak, dark chocolate, roasted malt, vague raisiny fruitiness, sweet alcohol. Fluffy moussey body, devilish and great.

On draft at Capones for the Lost Abbey dinner. Pours a deep black with a thin sliver of beige foam. Nose is chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, toffee and oak.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel, boozy and warming.  Real good

A black colored beer, with a dark beige head. The aroma of dark malt, vanilla, wood and dark fruits. The taste of dark malt, dark fruits, vanilla, whisky notes wood and notes of alcohol. The aftertaste is sweet a little bitter with notes of alcohol

Dark brown with ruby edges and a thin tan head. The nose is a mélange of the various barrels and some roasted aromatics. Full bodied, rich chocolate and port- like flavors on the mid palate before a quick transition to sweeter elements on the back end. There is a lift on the finish that plays perfectly with the soft mouthfeel. Amazing.

In short: A corpulent chocolaty, caramelized, fruity and woody big dark beer.  Excellent sipper
How: Bottle 375ml.  A few times.  This rating for a bottles aged almost one year, slightly better than when fresh.
The look: Near black body with red highlights topped by a very small beige head
In long: Nose is a big fat fruity chocolaty cake, or maybe dark chocolate coasted fruits.  Whatever, it has fruits and chocolate, and it smells like a billions calories.  Decadent.  Taste is still the rich chocolate and the avalanche of fresh juicy fruits (raisins, fresh dark fruits and red fruits, sweet apples), but also a lot of nice vanilla beans.  Also some anise star spiciness.  There is quite a bit of wood in there and with the rich caramel bordering maple syrup, I had a maple wood sensation.  Finish is inexplicably relatively dry. This slightly aged bottle was less hot/boozy than the fresh bottle I first had and also it was a lot more homogenous.  From my experience this is not surprising with big heavy blended beers (the Sinners lineup comes to mind, especially the 09) where a fresh bottle really tastes like a bunch of different beers poured in one glass, but with a bit of time the blend becomes one beer.  The slightly aged bottle Im rating right now is a bit better than the fresh bottle I drank a while ago but I dont think this beer will benefit of any more aging.  This is now a cohesive beer and I dont see how it can improve.  An excellent sipper.  This Deliverance is an excellent blend, and I love beer blends, every night I blend 3 or 4 in my stomach.

Bottle shared by Dreadnaught33. Thanks Jonathan!

Deep brown hue, bordering on black with a good sized beige head that leaves a healthy amount of lacing on the glass. The aroma is of brandy, alcohol, and roasted malt. The taste follows suit. The feel is medium to thick in body with a very strong alcohol presence, most notably brandy. This is a very tasty beer and definitely worthwhile. Great for sharing a few ways, as this is best in small doses.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-12-2010

Bottle from Brill & Co in June 2012.

Black with a minimal head. This was a lovely one, especially the taste. Complex with malt, licorice, port wine, dark fruit and some light notes of smoke. Nice body and mouth feel. Vinous and with a long aftertaste.

@ Basunen: lätt mjölkig doft. Trevlig smak. Ganske fyllig. Trevliga halv brända toner. Lätt rökighet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Fantastisk øl. Korn, malt, rugbrød, blommer, svesker, portvin, vinøs, træ, tøv, sort, sød, let bitter, sirups, blød, stor smag.

Sampled from a 12.7 oz corked brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a medium sized foamy brown head that faded and left minimal lacing. The aroma was bourbon, cognac, vanilla, candied dark fruits and wood. The flavor was a marvelously complex and swirling blend of rich toasty malts, bourbon, vanilla, coconut, cherry, cognac, cocoa, molasses and tobacco. The finish was very long and complex with flavor that came in waves and lingered forever. Moderately full bodied and the alcohol was remarkably well hidden. Marvelous!
By far one of my favorite strong ales, as well as beer from the lost abbey crew.  Shared with Mark, James, Bill and Jared after drinking

Draft at SIBF (multiple times! lucky us). Blackest brown, hazed brown head. Heavy stout malt nose, great medium, restrained mix of the big LA beers. Rich fruit, bourbon. Just what the angels share needed. Very tasty.

Mild carbonation, whispy head and oily texture, golden resin appearance, alcohol cloyed well in aroma with an enticing brandy scent and burnt sugar, no bitter lingering aftertaste, leaving me a bit dry and warmed up, In the taste department, I was left a bit unfufilled. Yet a very nice medium body hybrid.
Strong yet smooth taste with an amazing bourbon aftertaste.  Great pour with a smooth head.
Nice subtle aroma of cherries and bourbon. Favorite is dry, slight hoppiness. Like a barrel aged dry stout, lots of hot alcohol. Not as hoppy as I expected.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2012 Bottle 375ml @ home
Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma has notes of malt, chocolate, alcohol, vanilla and oak. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter with a long sweet, boozy, oaky and vanilla finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft.

Dark brown with a quickly dying brown head. Quite lovely barrel aroma with heavy dark malts showing notes of chocolate, toffe, cookie dough, cold coffe and cocoa. Bourbon is prominent alongside alcohol but still inviting in a very american way. Mouthfeel is sticky with sharp carbonation and the flavor is similar to the aroma though with more sharp alcohol and hard roasted malts. Quite edgy and almost Brewdog like in the hotness, nothing alittle age wont fix (hopefully) quite tasty.

Pours dark with frizzy light brown head which quickly disappears
Aromas of plums, port, raisins, almost blueberry like, alcohol, dark chocolate
Nice rich creamy and sweet palate. Somewhat sticky from alcohol. Low bitter ending.
Tastes of chocolate, Dark fruits, alcohol, some oak, raisins.
This is overall a very fine tuned american strong ale that I would really like to get my hands on again

bottle= pours black with a big tan head. nose is strong oak aged spirits, candied figs, roasted marshmellows, vanilla-y, chocolaty, smooth aromas, considerably ponderable aroma. taste is big too. rounded strong bourbon and vinous features with a really hot finish. borderline cloyingly sweet, it might be a little too much. But its a fab beer.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black color with a tan head. Aroma is of lots of bourbon, oak, vanilla, nice sweetness from the brandy, dark fruits, some alcohol, bourbon soaked dark fruit, cocoa nib, liquorice, roasted malt and tobacco. The flavor follows the nose, yet it is much smoother. I get bourbon, oak, vanilla, the sweet brandy like flavor, dark fruits, bourbon soaked dark fruits, cocoa nib, roasted malt, liquorice, dark caramel, tobacco and some coffee. The body is full with a creamy mouth feel. Overall a really nice blended brew!

Pours from bottle a deep, dark brown with minimal tan head. After a burst of sharpie marker, an overwhelming aroma of buttery brown sugar with tones of dark fruit and bourbon. Sweet but not syrupy--vanilla, bourbon, and alcohol all present. Soft but lingering palate that makes me shivvvvver. Sure does beat a box of chocolates for an anniversary gift!

Bottled. Pours black with a small tan head. Nose of burbon, berries and dark fruits. Sweet flavor with dark fruits, and berries along with brown sugar, vanilla and bourbon. Full bodied, oily to syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Ends up with a alcohol touch. A world class beer.

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. Pours dark brown with small light brown head. Aromas of bourbon, dark fruits, caramel, roasted malts, and oak. Sweet molasses and bourbon flavors with burnt malts, brandy, oak, and some alcohol. Full body with moderate carbonation and a thick, creamy mouthfeel. A nice beer, but I think I prefer the two beers on their own. Thanks Craig.

bottle.  Pours a very dark brown, but not black.  There seems to be little to no carbonation with this beer as it pours with no head at all.  The aroma is top notch.  Get a lot of raisins, dark cherries, bourbon, and just overall greatness coming from the smell, a lot going on.  The taste was interesting, complex, but yet finishes with almost a cough drop bitterness to it.  It leaves you wanting more out of the flavor based on the aroma.  A good, but not great beer.

My rating for this beer is only as high as it is because of the aroma element of the score. Why do I keep buying from this brewer? The first beer I had was Angels Share, and it was infected and disgusting. The brewer pretty much told me to suck it when I suggested they consider compensating me in some small way.

Ok, on to this beer. I had my eye on this beer for months, but told myself "No, I will not buy such a pricey beer that will certainly NOT be worth the cost. And besides, this brewer knowingly sells infected batches of their very expensive beer and then tells their customers to go....themselves when the beer is spoiled." But....on a whim....as I stood there in the beer section....it called my named......."Oh Miiiiichael......you know you want me". So, like an idiot, thinking only with my palate, I fell for its charms.

Initially, I thought I had a winner. This things opened with only a slight hiss of carbonation from the bottle. Immediately putting my nose to the bottle I smelled....raisins. Not a bad thing. That usually means interesting things are in store for me. 

The pour was black...light does not return from this one. Head? There is really no head. Carbonation....only a tingle, really. The aroma....oh the aroma. I love the aroma of this one. Raisins, alcohol, soy, cherries, chocolate....on another day, I probably would get even more. I could sit and smell this for a while and be perfectly happy.

Taste.....ok, this was a surprise. I was expecting big things here. A big taste. I was pretty sure I would come down on the side of, "Needs mellowing. Needs time in the cellar". No way. This thing is subtle. If you go into it expecting to be blown away, you will be surprised. The flavors are all there; chocolate, bourbon, dark cherries, alcohol...no doubt more. But they are working together, and they are not going to smack you in the face. Youll have to take some time to notice them.

Ultimately, I think this is a pretty good beer, but it lacks something. Its simply not enough. I am left wanting something more from this. It is definitely unique. Its interesting. It has surprises. It is very expensive, but then most barrel aged beers are expensive. For me, the ultimate indicator is, would I buy it again...at $20 a bottle. Probably not. Certainly not in the next year.

I initially bought this to consider whether I wanted to age it. After trying it, I must say, it might get less interesting with age. I do not think that it needs mellowing. Its already mellow. Its done the aging thing already. Its "thinner" than I expected, and it does not need to lose mouth-feel.

See you in 5 years.

No no no. Dont do that. Its going to know its a trap, Dee. Thats going to irritate the cat, and then its going to dig itself down further and we may never get to it. Lets start thinking like a cat here, alright? You know - we need another cat. Thats what we need. Heres what were going to do. Im going to crack a little hole in your wall - a tiny one, itll be cool - and then Im going to slip a second cat in with a string tied around it. Those two will become codependent, then Ill rip the second cat out and the first one hopefully, hopefully will follow.

Pours thick and dark with a small brown head. Nose is big vanilla, molasses, brown sugar, chocolate, boozy and wood. Taste is sweet and very lightly bitter. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Soft. Heavy body with a long aftertaste. Decadent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, corked. Looking quite cute, with its dark brown body topped by a dense, finger thick tan head. From there its just upwards. The aroma, I dont know how to describe it, I was completely blown away. Sweetness, molasses, alcohol, something peat-like, lots of dried fruits, some medicine and a touch of spicyness in a wonderful mix, making it quite hard to start tasting. And wheres the alcohol hidden? I can feel it in the mouth, theres some notes of vanilla in the flavor, revealing its bourbon ageing, but that 12.5% ABV is sure well hidden. Flavorwise, its equally as wonderful as the aroma, complex as hell, and damn its tasteful. The finish is more on the roasted side than the initial flavor, and lasts for ages. Super smooth, full-bodied and warming, its next to a sexual experience just feeling it swirl around, caressing the palate oh so softly and careful. Damn, Ive never been as close to a 4.7 before. Someone send me another bottle please. 110930

Great complex aroma with the booze really apparent. Black with brown highlights and mimimla brown head.  Chocolate, caramel, oak, vanilla - massively complex. Chewy and dry mouthfeel. I would have rated lower when straight out of the fridge - so much better as it warmed up and became well rounded and complex.

This blend pours a deep, dark, murky brown with a tan diminishing head and good lacing.  Deep aroma of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, coffee and port with hints of cherry.  Full body and great flavor thats not overly alcoholic given this is a blend of two strong barrel-aged ales.

Bottle shared at home.  Virtually black pour with a small tan head.  Aroma is massive bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, caramel. Hot damn. Delicious. All the expected players make an appearance with the addition of some tart, earthy woods. Very nice. The booze is nicely incorporated.

The feel is what I was concerned about. I had heard from countless people that Lost Abbey beers are notoriously flat. This is far from flat. Velvety smooth, beautiful.

Overall, I desperately wish we could get Lost Abbey here in the north woods. If their other beers are even half as good as this, I would be their biggest customer. WANT.

Ive had this beer a bunch of different times, on draft and out of the bottle. Figured I might as well finally review this while its current on-tap at my house. Poured from the kegerator into a Bruery tulip. 2010 vintage.

A - Pours black, mocha-colored head, thin film on top, spotty lace, thick collar. 

S - Big chocolate, both milk and dark, booze, vanilla, brownies, and oak. Still pretty boozy, even after a year and and half worth of age, but its definitely smoothed out since it was fresh. Very sweet, reminds me of a rich dessert.

T - Chocolate syrup on top of chocolate brownies with a small side of bourbon. Theres a touch of oak and vanilla in there as well. The alcohol bite makes the finish bitter and boozy, yet still remaining somewhat sweet.

M - Full, rich and smooth, good carbonation, creamy finish. Even after almost two years, this one is still quite boozy. That said, its really smoothed out since I had it fresh, and its definitely more enjoyable now then ever. I think another year will do this some more good...might be perfect by then!

Its a blend of bourbon barrel aged Serpent Stout and brandy barrel aged The Angels Share.

Theres more brandy than bourbon in both the nose and the flavor, and the alcohol is very restrained for the 12.5% abv

The flavor is immensely complex with brandy, chocolate, caramel, raisin, (big) plum, fig, date, pecan, leather, tobacco, vanilla, oak, rum, cardamom, and a touch of smoke.

The body is more silky than syrupy, and the carbonation is very soft and minimal.

This is a perfect marriage of the two beers, and I find it a notch or two better than even Firestone Walker 15, and definitely the best (non sour) beer that Ive tasted from Lost Abbey.

With the smell you can definitely tell that the Angels Share took over this beer.  If I would guess on the blend I would say 75% AS and maybe 25% Serpents Stout.  Still its pretty damn unique and amazing.  The Brandy presence comes through nicely, mixed in with a butterscotch aroma, caramel, dark fruits, vanilla, and oak.  Small amount of booze.  Its lovely. 

Taste is just as good.  Its a nice and sweet taste.  Once again the inviting presence of butterscotch. Chocolate, Caramel, brown sugar, dark fruits, vanilla, bourbon, brandy, and oak.  Its complex.  The alcohol is more noticeable in the taste.  But sitting at 12.50% what do you expect.  Its a sipper.  Its to be enjoyed over a long period of time.  No need to rush with this one.

Mouthfeel is thick, smooth, and creamy.  It coats the tongue and just sits there.

Sample at Central Waters anniversary party.  Deep brown/black with no head.  Soft cocoa, lightly roasted malts, sweet vanilla, and faint bourbon.  Flavor is velvety chocolate, lightly sweet residual malt, a touch of roasted malt, vanilla, bourbon, and faint dark fruit.  Palate is ultra smooth and feels thinner than expected.  Residual cocoa and sweet, stick malt.  Dangerously drinkable.
From a tap,dark red in color,minimum brownish head,bourbon notes,its ok but definitely not worth $15 a 350ml bottle.

Aroma is full of bourbon and brandy notes that intertwine and really make the boozy nature of this beer apparent. The appearance of this beer is a deep dark brown color that is almost black but not. It pours with a brown/mocha colored head that fades away quickly. The taste is really very interesting. You can taste the two beers individually in each sip. When you take a sip you first are blasted with the brandy barrel-aged Angels share which is quickly soothed by the smooth texture of the bourbon barrel-aged serpent stout. It is a wonderfully complex beer that even at the 12.5% ABV makes me wonder if that is simply what the blend is before going into the barrel together.

Bottle.  Pours a murky brown with caramel colored head.   Aroma of roast, caramel, chocolate, and dark fruit.  Some vanilla notes and earthiness.   Sweet roasty chocolate taste with dark fruit, bitters, and vanilla notes on the back end.  Spice from the barrel.  This one is hot.  Very good.  But should age gracefully.   Smooth out some.

Aroma of cherry, molasses, vanilla and strong toffee.  Pours deep black/red with a medium tan head.  Tastes delicious with coffee, chocolate cherries and just a hint of toffee.  Fantastic brew and a little too easy to drink.  I want more of these!

Bottle thanks to Santa.  Huge thanks!  Almost black pour, opaque with some good signs of carbonation.  Thanks Lost Abbey!  Left a small beige head that faded quickly to thin collar.  The Angels Share jumped out of the glass first with big notes of brandy, wood and caramel.  The SS lingered in the background with small hints of chocolate.  Flavors were quite boozy.  Lots of caramel, brandy, hints of wood and a mild cocoa finish.  The SS added a roasty complexity to the mix of sweet boozy goodness that is Angels Share.  Overall this blend worked nicely, quite complex with lots going on.  Cant wait for another bottle...

Poured into snifter, no head, dark but not impy stout dark. Strong brandy vanilla head, reminiscent of the angels share. Bold smokey flavors up front, vanilla and oak, bourbon and brandy, getting a lot more of the strong ale than the stout. Very interesting, will try it again, despite the price tag.

Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Almost black - offwhite head. Bourdon, coconut, light burned notes, roasted, fruity, raisins, dried fruits, dark sugar, vanilla, light boozy notes, wooden, high sweetness, light sharpness, light bitterness, licorice. Low carbonation. Nice.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a thick tan head. Smells intense but subtle. The Angels share pops out first, full-on brandy complexity. Some sophisticated chocolate and word follows. Earthy. Bourbon. Prune. Vanilla. Brown sugar. A hint of pepper. So very complicated, and intricate.

The taste is a clear blend of the two beers, Angels Share followed closely by Serpents Stout, and finishes dry with a hint of dry semisweet fruity malty chocolate.

Very smooth creamy texture. Full bodied.

I think this may be the most complicated and best beer Ive ever imbibed. I dont have words to meet it.

This beer has just the right amount of alcohol flavor for a 12 percent beer. The carbonation is light as expected but the mouthfeel is not as thick as I imagined. The taste is good and complex, the bourbon and brandy are to thank, and they are not too overpowering. All in all a good beer but with a price this high it is good on occasion. However on harsh comparison it is hard to justify on taste alone, but when considering the effort required to make a blended barrel aged masterpiece, you wont think twice.

Opaque black color with a thin, tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of dark fruits, roasted malts, red wine, vanilla, toffee, wood, and alcohol. Taste of red wine, roast, various dark fruits, vanilla, sherry wood, and some alcohol in the finish.

Bottle from vtafro.  Deep brown in color with just a wisp of a khaki head.  Very low, but still present, carbonation.  Aroma has chocolate, oak, grahm cracker, grapes and apple skin, and some vanilla.  Decadent to say the least.  Taste is toffee, chocolate, vanilla, grapes, prunes, and some oak notes.  This is great.  Rich, warming, and a perfect mix of sweet and bitter.

Opened this one as a night cap. After aging it for a year I thought it was time to finally try it. The beer poured an opaque dark brown to black with a thin layer of light brown head. Aroma includes: coconut, vanilla, dark chocolate, and hints of brandy. The taste is pretty much the same with slight hints of alcohol esters. Overall, the only criticism I have is that the body could be a little more thick for 12.5% ABV
Pours dark brown.  Aroma is bourbon, dark fruits, sweet malts, and more bourbon.  Taste is toffee, vanilla, caramel, dark fruits, and booze.  Warm finish and smooth palate.

375 mL bottle from Plaza Liquors in Tucson, served in a branded stem glass. Pours chestnut-black with a small tan head. The head fades quickly and leaves a small amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are notes of bourbon, molasses, brandy, oak, roast malts, raisins, earth, herbs, alcohol and subtle smoke. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with roasted stout notes, figs and chocolate, along with bourbon, brandy, oak and raisins from the nose. Towards the end, a mild earthy hop bitterness enters along with prominent pepper and spice. The finish is long, spicy and roasty with bourbon and brandy notes. On the palate, it is full in body, with a syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a truly beautiful beer that combines flavour notes from brandy-barrelled Angels Share and bourbon-barrelled Serpents Stout. Bourbon barrels predominate slightly, but the roast malts from the Serpents Stout provide a nice accent. This makes me wish I had more barrel-aged Lost Abbey brews! Truly excellent. 2011-12-01

Dark brown/black color; Medium to heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, molasses, vanilla, & some bourbon; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, molasses, syrup, chocolate, dark fruit, and some vanilla; Warm finish; Nicely balanced & complex; Very good overall.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown/black with thin tan head.  Nice lacing.  Carbonation...wow.  Nice after the last Angels Share drain pour I had.  Aroma has tons of toffee, caramel, vanilla, brandy and oak.  Unreal nose.  Taste of bourbon, vanilla, toffee, caramel, cherries and maple syrup.  Full, thick, and creamy mouthfeel.  Every taste is great.  Tons of flavor with lots of bourbon and brandy.  Love it.  Top 5 for me.

Pours a dark brownish black with a little to no head and low carbonation. Aroma is tobacco, brandy, cherries, and oak. The taste is amazing, thick and strong and sweet. Lots of alcohol as well. A perfect blend of two amazing beers.

375ml.  Pricy bastard, lets see if its worth it.  Pours a black body, minimal head, however carbonation is better than expected.  Aromas are vanilla and bourbon really pulling through, overwhelming which I enjoy.  Very smooth and balanced, the sweetness from the bourbon goes straight through the palate, creamy and long finish.  ABV is well hidden for sure.  Excellent offering.

Tasted on 10/12/11 from a corked and caged 375mL bottle.  Pours completely opaque, nearly black, with a thin tan head that leaves whispy lace, and a nice collar.  The nose is dusty milk and dark chocolate, with tons of oaky vanilla, bourbon, molasses, maple, a hint of coffee, and a light earthy aroma that really rounds everything out nicely.  The flavor is darker, but with the same profile.  Dark chocolate, coffee, loads of oaky vanilla, molasses, sweet licorice, maple, and the same earthy note all come through nicely, all balanced by light bitterness.  The body is full, with light (but just right) carbonation, and a long chocolate, coffee, earthy oak, sweet licorice, and lightly tannic finish.

12oz bottle from NobleSquirrel, thanks Brian 
Appearance: Black with a small dark tan head with some spotty lacing 
Aroma: Dark fruit, milk chocolate, bourbon, oak with some hot alcohols 
Taste: Silky mouthfeel of roasted malts, vanilla and woody 
Very nice and drinkable, this would have held up and been even better in a few years.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with BeerandBlues2 in Dec.of 2010.  Color is a near solid mahogany with very low carbonation and almost no head.  Aroma of oak, brandy and dark fruit.  Its full bodied with a rich mouth feel.  Flavor is big and bold with oak, dry fruits and brandy then a mild bitterness.  After taste lets the sweet flavors linger with just a touch of alcohol showing.  Overall this is a wonderful brew, may be the best Ive had from Lost Abbey.
Bottle thanks to Tim and Rachel (Tally Crew): Poured a black brown with little to no head. Aroma is very sweat and brandy. Taste is a mix of malts, chocolate, and loads of brandy/bourbon alcohol.

(375ml bottle) near black pour but no head at all, surprise surprise. Nose is very complex, vanilla, bourbon, brandy, barrel, graham cracker and milk chocolate. Taste of bourbon, raisin, alcohol, smooth, milk chocolate, brandy, vanilla (real!), complex and excellent.

Bottke. Pours black with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, coffee, nuts and soy sauce. Flavor is sweer and roasted with some soy sauce and caramel. Medium to full body, soft carbonation. Really nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2012 Ill make it simple. This company does everything right.

Strong roast and chocolate notes. Dry coffe, chocolate and bitter flavors. Add some hops and water and look out. 

Re -rate 2/21/12  On draft at Issacs. FFS Tremendous.

Jet black colour, no head, no carbonation,light lace. huge aromas, very wine like mixed with malted roast notes. i get a hint of oak as well. very complex and has a real boozy sweetness that comes out as well. On the palate it is hot and boozy with rich vanilla and butterscotch notes and charcoal. very long length. very complex. very very nice

375ml bottle. Pours a very dark, opaque brown with almost no head at all and the thinnest ring of lace. Huge malt presence on the nose with lots of coffee, dark chocolate and licorice. The brandy is fairly subdued on the nose but theres also a lot of stewed fruit and a certain earthy quality. Weighty and rich on the palate with most of the notes from the nose coming through. Long warm finish.

Pours deep brown/black with a thin mocha head.  Aroma is very roasty and complex with notes of dark fruit...fig...bourbon, vanilla, chocolate...winey and boozy.  Flavor has smooth vanilla and bourbon up front with subtle dark fruit following...spicy hop notes, slightly winey, fig...sweet and roasty.  Mouthfeel is creamy...only slightly lively...with a very roasty, warming finish that displays nice bourbon.  Awesome.

12.7oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours black with a thick, lacy, tan head.  Aroma strong of roasted malts, chocolate, a little coffee, bourbon and brandy and the alcohol that comes with these, and some nice hops to balance it out.  Flavor an incredible blend of these two beers that are both great on their own - the Serpents stout and bourbon really come through in the aftertaste.  Thick and smooth.  A great beer.

Bottle poured into snifter.  Black, no head, a few bubbles around the edge 
of the glass.  Aroma is:  Bourbon, chocolate,  coconut, raisin and a tart wine like twang at the end. Flavor is: chocolate, coconut, bourbon, wood, booze.  It finishes with a tart brandy note.  This beer would be so much better without the brandy barrel.  I havent cared much for the double barrel aged beers.  Mouthfeel was a big let down, but I knew there was a chance for little to no carbonation.  More bubbles would have made this a much better 
beer too.  Dissapointing.

Poured into a snifter. Thanks to PretzelCity for this.

3.5 A: Black color. One finger of creamy light brown head that has average retention given the ABV and leaves no lacing.

5.0 S: I personally didnt care much for regular Serpents and Im not a huge fan of any brandy barrel beer, but this combination is exquisite. The bourbon is a lot stronger than the brandy and the resulting intensity from each blends together almost perfectly. Anyway, the bourbon in this is smooth with a low booziness. Flavors include a good bit of leather, toastiness, a slight touch of peat, and subtle fruitiness. The brandy adds a nice vinous component. The barrels add a good bit of vanilla and oak. The underlying stouts lend a surprisingly soft roastiness with plenty of sweet caramel and molasses. A light sugariness with dark fruits and emphasis on plum and raisin. Very, very nice.

4.5 T: I dont know what this was like fresh, but at this point its quite smooth and the booze is well in check. Bourbon and brandy again work very well together. Ive had a few other bourbon + brandy beers and none of them have worked together at all, let alone as well as they do in this brew. Leathery bourbon with touches of peat and char. Woody, vinous brandy. Again good vanilla and oak. The base beers play second fiddle to the barrel treatments, but this is so good that I dont care (I usually do). Lots of caramel, molasses, and some brown sugar. Plum, raisin, prune, and tobacco fruitiness.

4.0 M: Medium to perhaps heavier medium body. Carbonation is a bit lower that what is typical for the style, but it works just as well. The problem is that this is missing the rich, velvety creaminess that I come to expect from beers of this nature. Very smooth though.

4.5 D: Best LA beer Ive had. I didnt think Id enjoy this nearly as much as I have, but Im glad I did.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-13-2011 23:14:51

The most carbonated beer Ive had from LA in ages a frothy 2mm head after a vigorous poor. Its a solid brew. I no longer drop cash on LA myself- I figure if they dont care enough to fix the carbonation problem I dont care enough to drop the cash. I am still glad I received this beer as a toss in on a trade. If it was carbonated properly it would be a 5 Im certain. As delivered it is what it is: a 13 yr old boy- totally flat and loaded with potential. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Thnx 2 tarheels86 for this. One word: amazing. Very soft, silky, great. Roast, bourbon, chocolate, caramel and warming alcohol. Mmmmmjammy.
Bottle, thanx to tkrjukoff. Pours black with a small, light brown head. Deep aroma of oak, vanilla, dryed fruit and alcohol. Flavour of oak, vanilla and licorice. Well balanced.

Traded bottle. I really liked this and was happy that it was not overpowering. Pours jet black and my was (thankfully) carbonated. Just a thin brown head but I was happy. This beer was tough to nail down but now that I read the description and honestly seemed liked a stout blended with a barleywine. I really liked it. Plus the 12+ ABV was well hidden. Very nice.

Its definitely a shape shifter, this one. I didnt really know what I was tasting at the time, but I certainly picked up on the combination of barrel aged stout and barleywine. I poured dark brown with a tiny bit of light setting off some ruby hues at the edges. Almost no foam. The aroma is caramel, heavy bourbon, raisins, and plum. The flavor is massive with lots of bourbon, raisins, and underlying notes of roasted malt. It changes with every sip sometimes giving off a more chocolaty impression. Very alcoholic and a challenge to drink very much of, but a beer that will leave an impression for sure.

Bottle looks very, very good. Beer in the glass black as the night, almost no head. Extrem roasty malty aroma. Starts very strong with intense notes of chocolate, burning alcoholic. Heavy malty finish, gets drier and drier, also bitter coffee notes. Warming finish, intense maltiness. Impressive beer, but it could be more balanced.

Wonderfully complex beer that evolves as you drink it.  This beer poured black with a thin tan head.  It was very rich and smooth on the palate with medium to low carbonation.  Aroma was bourbon, chocolate, coffee, toffee, dark fruits.  Taste is similar to the aroma with bourbon dominating a bit but not overpowering.  The stout elements are really nice in this.  The roasted flavors compliment the bourbon and vanilla perfectly.  As this beer warmed the brandy came through quite a bit more with notes of dark fruits.  A great beer experience found sitting on the shelf at liquor store.

375ml bottle thanks to Bradbalk. Pours black with a thin tan head. Aroma is huge roast, bourbon, vanilla, burnt sugar, ethanol, grilled stone fruit, sweet dark fruit, layers of chocolate, licorice and spice waft up with a gentle sniff. Flavor is bourbon, roast, chocolate and vanilla up front, waves of hot ethanol seep in toward the middle, without the bourbon notes they would be a little over the top, but that lovely oakey goodness helps to balance it out, finishes with dark fruit vanilla, alcohol, toasted sweet breads and dark, rich caramel. Palate is hugely heavy in body, creamy and slick on entry increasingly slick toward the dry, slightly boozy finish (again the bourbon notes save it here), throw in a light but noticeable carbonation and you have a delicious sort of black barleywine/imperial stout contraption. It really changes as it warms, lots more dark fruit and brandy notes as it gets toward room temp. I really enjoyed this beer.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2011 Bottle found sitting on the shelf this week, This is the best blend of barrel aged beers Ive ever had. Bourbon and roasted Malts dominate the nose but with some patience you can detect the brandy. The flavor is different from the aroma but equally and well balanced. A finish that lasts forever, vanilla and bourbon. Great job lost abbey!

bottle  9/24/10.

Hazy red-orange-brown shade of black with a small tannish head.

Holy fudgey bourbon aroma! Very warming. Mixed with some lesser notes of roast, spice, cherries and ash.

The flavor is the same. Very rich and delicious. dessert-like. A bourbon-y sting comes through as it warms.

Medium/full body but alcohol cuts through to make it incredibly quaffable.9/4/9/5/18/4.5+

(Bottle, thanks tkrjukoff!) Pours black with a small light brown head. The aroma holds smooth roast alongside a fantastic barrel mix - I pick up both the bourbon and the brandy. Also clear tones of (Belgian) esters - both dried and fresh fruits, Belgian chocolate, fat caramel and some alcohol. Subtle spices and tiny earthy/leafy hops. Almost creamy, coconut and vanilla notes as the beer gets warmer. Fantastic complex and deep nose, almost a bit romantic. The flavour is near medium sweet, light to medium bitter and tiny, tiny acidic. Complex barrel ageing, smooth, luxury chocolate, dried fruits, caramel and wood shop. The mouthfeel is round, smooth, creamy and velvety with a light carbonation. Quite fiery. Lingering wooden and malty finish. Nar full bodied. Super!

Bottle shared thx to tkrjukoff 2011-07-09 Sätila
AR: caramel, roasted caramel malt, red wine
AP: pitch black, wee beige head
F: vinos, warming, roasted malt and vanilla

Bottle 37,5 cl. Pours pitch black with a small bubbly brown head leaving some lace. Aroma is fruity, fullboduied, sweet, malty, vanilla and oak barrel; well in balance. Flavor is like aroma, pungeant, tingly on tounge; excellent balance. Finishes yet again balanced between bitter, oak, malt and alcohol.

Bottle, thanks to tkrjukoff. Black beer with a small beige head. Sweet oaky whiskey aroma, creamy and with vanilla notes. Whiskry flavor, roasted, vanilla, cream, chocolate, malt, toffee, hoppy grassy notes, some metal. Lovely balance in this beer. Oaky, woody and with coconut notes. Long warming finish. Truly a great beer!

This poured a medium to darker brown color with a very small basically non existent tan head. Aroma was lots of bourbon and brandy, dark chocolate, and dark fruits too, some molasses as well. Flavor was much the same as the aromas, lots of deep dark roasted chocolate, lots of boozy brandy and bourbon too. Great Stuff.

375mL bottle, and one of the best sounding blends Ive ever heard of.  Poured deeper, rather murky brown with a rich toasted tan head.. looked very good in the glass.  The aroma picked up just what I needed.. well-roasted licorice, rich vinous fruits, and sweeter chocolate accented by vanilla and most enjoyable bourbon.. peppery notes and alcohol warmth on the back of the nose.. everything worked together.. awesome stuff!  The flavor opened with a syrupy foray of molasses and lesser maple, with bitter licorice, aged caramel, and vanilla settling onto the middle.. tangy oak, sweet bourbon, and black peppery alcohol around.. finished with more of the barrel and warmth, but neither got out of hand.  Heavier-bodied with low, but enough carbonation on the palate.. it really let the brew flow at its own pace through the mouth.. warm belly and warmth in the nose after the drink, and I loved every minute of it.

Thanks to bungletronics for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is outstanding. I get a lot of roasted malt, along with some alcohol and chocolate. 

The flavor is also excellent. The chocolate and roasted malt notes are great and those are complimented with a lot of notes from the bourbon barrel aging. I get some nice bourbon notes, as well as some maple and vanilla. There is also a little bit of nuttyness in the flavor which compliments the other parts very well. 

Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. One of the best Lost Abbey beers I have tried.

12.7oz bottle thanks to luckyhank.  pours a light black / dark brown with no head - the bottle gave a nice pop.  Very nice nose full of bourbon, light brandy, dark fruits, oak, light Belgian yeast and sugar.  Full heavy body - almost syrupy.  The barrel notes really shine across the mouth with the brandy barrels coming through stronger than on the nose.  Bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, fig, oak, grapes, apple, raisins and sweet residual sugars fill the mouth.  Somewhat hot finish with deep fruit layers combined with more barrel notes, chocolate, molasses and sweet sugars.

375 ml bottle. Dark pour with thin tan head. Big chocolate ations with aome boubon. Flavor is mild to start out vanilla choclate and carmel. Finishes with a mild boozy note, but not too strong. Very well balenced for a bi ba beer

BIG thanks to Trappistlover for this much welcomed surprise!

A: Yet another extremely black beer, however this one has some fantastic carbonation that sticks around throughout the journey! Wasnt expecting that since its barrel aged and a Lost Abbey beer. I am seeing some good lacing, thick and sticky.

S: Mmmm delicious bourbon my favorite. Getting some oak, vanilla, big O malt, maybe some leather, hints of brandy but the bourbon pretty much overpowers it. Definitely detecting chocolate too. Alcohol is prevalent but not overpowering to me, although I tend to enjoy the big boozy stouts.

T: Oh yeah, thats daddys medicine right there, love this! Getting the port wine brandy flavor and the bourbon aftertaste. Mild burn as it goes down but not too much. Definitely taste some vanilla but its subtle I only notice it after the beer fully coats and sits awhile. I am also getting some bitter chocolate but that could be the booze talking...

O: I really enjoy this beer, too bad its hard to find and expensive. As I said before this is always a much welcomed treat! Thanks Dave.

Bottled.  Pours a dark brown to black color with a small beige head.  This looks more like the stout.  The aroma is big sweet malts, dark fruits, bourbon and dark chocolate.  The flavor shows both the bourbon and sweeter brandy notes, dark chocolate, caramel, ripe dark fruits and alcohol.  The abv is noticeable, but with this beer not distracting.  I am a big fan.

A hearty thanks to my cousin for cracking open this beauty!  So it is half bourbon barrel aged stout + half brandy barrel aged Angels Share (which is a barley wine, I think, and a superb, top-rated brew on its own).  Interesting aroma is malty, sweet, and floral.  The barrel aging and blending results in a beer that is very complex and flavorful.  There is a lot going on - warmth, coffee, sharp hops, a touch of brandy, some bourbon notes, an interesting sensation on the palate - and it is all blended nicely and in balance.  This really is something special - awesome brew!

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: I was afraid this bottle was going to explode all over the place like their Framboise de Amorosa did, so I opened this bottle in the shower. Luckily, I will be able to enjoy the whole bottle and instead of having to share the majority of the bottle with my floor.  Once poured, a beautiful beer fills my English pint glass with a dark mahogany liquid with a brown tint. There was a creamy yet delicate layer of foam head that lasted around throughout the drink.  As for the nose, a rich and robust scent of sweet sugary malt and earthy wood barrel dominate the aroma.  The palate is so smooth and gentle like a soft piece of velvet, but there is still a moderate level of carbonation. Flavors explode on the taste buds of my tongue and range from a mixture or earthy notes of wood barrel, vanilla, cocoa powder, maple syrup and a touch of sweet spice such as cinnamon. The finish is a rich aftertaste and leaves behind a trace of pumpkin pie.  This is truly delighting ale, and feel so lucky to have gotten to drink it.

12.7oz. bottle from Justin.  Release date Aug. 28, 2010.  Appears to pour black, but when held to a bright light, is really reddish/brown.  Head is tan.  Though it dissipates fairly rapidly, gentle swirriling will maintain a moderate head.  A lot of pop when opened, but no overflow.  Aroma is bourbon/brandy, as it should be, with vanilla, faint dark fruit and roasted malt.  Taste is bourbon/brandy through and through, with vanilla, some dark fruit and just a touch of chocolate. Body is thickish and syrupy.  Finish is smooth and boozy.  This is a fantastic ale.

375ml Bottle - No apparent bottling date.  Pours a dark black/brown with creamy tan head.  Aroma is chocolate malt, cocoa, brown sugar, wood/barrel, caramel, toffee, coffee, bourbon, vanilla, brandy, and some heat.  Taste is exactly the same; totally delicious blend of all the flavors, slight heat on the very tail end.  I imagine this beer is fairly fresh, and could definitely stand to age much longer. This could easily be close to a 5 point beer with some proper age on it.

28-05-11 Bouteille: Noir, avec un moyen collet de mousse blanche. Au premiers aromes, on croit sentir la angels share, cest  a dire brandy, sirop dérable, caramel, petits fruits. En la brassant  unpeu, le bourbon fait  surface, mais en puissance, en laissant également  de fortes notes de chocolats. Un de ces principaux  défauts  est  quelle est  trop sucrée et vue la puissance du bourbon, fini par  tomber sur le coeur. Mélange très complexe et très intéressant a essayer. Corps puissant avec une texture riche et crémeuse. Finale centrée sur le bourbon qui trop  de place et élimine les notes plus délicates de brandy et dérable.
Bottle thanks to bungletronics.  Deep brown with a khaki head.  Nose is brandy, wood, chocolate, and syrup.  Great palate, chocolate, brandy, wood, molasses, great finish.

bottle thanks to sean.  poured black with a thin beige head.  aroma was simply fantastic with fudge, grape, bourbon, vanilla, apple, and caramel.  flavor was fudge, grape, bourbon, alcohol, vanilla, and dark roast.  body was medium with low-medium carbonation.

Bottle split with ewestern, thanks Eric.  Aroma is sweet malts, bourbon, and oak.  Notes of dark fruit, molasses, maple syrup, brown sugar, vanillia, and chocolate.  Palate is chewey and thick.  Flavor is sweet bringing out a hint of coffee, finishing a little dry.  Damn good.

375 ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head that leaves a very small amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is pretty awesome.  Big bourbon, light vanilla, caramel, brandy, light leather, a bit of oak, chocolate, and a decent amount of alcohol.  All the flavors come together quite nicely.  The initial taste is sweet with some plum and bourbon.  You also get some caramel, oak, chocolate, and brandy.  The finish is pretty boozy with significant alcohol heat.  Medium body.  Low carbonation.  Enjoyable beer.  I would have rated the taste higher if there wasnt so much alcohol too it.  Im curious if this will get much better with time.

Pour is close to black but dark brown on the edges with a very small tan head. The head fades instantly and doesnt leave much lacing at all. Aroma is extremely boozy with some hints of vanilla, darker fruits, and roasted malts. Flavor is very heavy on the alcohol in both the body and the finish. Some hints of sweet vanilla, buttered bread, and chocolate, but its mostly just bourbon. Very thick and viscous mouth-feel.

Bottle from Capones. Pours out almost black with a thin tan head. Aroma is of sweet chocolate, bourbon, oak and raisin. Taste is complex with a nice silky smooth mouthfeel. Chocolate, oak, bourbon, fig, raisin, earth and the finish rounds off with a slight alcohol burn. Once again a top notch brew from Lost Abbey.

Small dark tan head, fades quickly dark dark brown nearly black with choc edges... Dark fruits and bourbon, some vanilla, choc, licorice, choc comes out as it warms... Intense though a bit muddled, semi sweet, some dark fruits, bourbon, light vanilla, and chocolate... Lively, full bodied, some alc though not overly present, a little creamy... WOW, loads of flavor, loads of aroma, intense...

Bottle from HH22... thanks tim... Shared at SL. Aroma is boooooozy, wow... lots of alcohol notes with some roasted malts and some chocolate...  Nice pour though.... Black, decent head. Taste reminded me of the angels share.... Boozy, alcohol notes, roasted malts with some nice chocolate bitterness. If the alcohol wasnt such a factor this beer would kick a$$. Medium body, kind of creamy, low carbonation. Either way a unique beer that I enjoyed. Thanks Tim

Bottle shared by Tooch4321...thanks Adam! - Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Brandy is apparent in the nose, along with tons of sweet dark malt and a bit of smokiness. The brandy/bourbon mix is much more pronounced in the taste, with tons of dark malt and yeasty, dark rye bread. Its flat as hell with a syrupy, thick body. Fun and complex, but fairly boozy and a little overbearing.
Black in color with slight tan head.  Woody vanilla complexity.  Incredibly smooth, roasty dominated with boozy wood and vanilla tones.  A great smooth, complex beer.

Bottle. Almost black, darky brown with a lightish tan head. Dark candied raisings, slight bourbon in the aroma, rounding sweetness, and a touch of dark fruits.  A bit more savory in the flavor, boozey, dark fruit, hint of chocolate.  Viscous and thicker body with tiny carbonation bubbles.  Good stuff.

Bottle, thanks for sharing tarheels. Pours dark brown/mahogany with a small, quickly disappearing yellow head. Aroma is buttery, bourbon, coconut, vanilla, a lot going on here. Just great. Flavor is sharp alcohol, bourbon, chocolate, coffee. Palate is oily. I cant really get into this, the aroma is great but the beer itself is a hot boozy mess.

Thanks to tarheels86. The pour is a moderately opaque dark brown with a frothy head that quickly disappears. Aroma is caramel is coffee, some roast, nothing too intense but definitely pleasant. Taste is caramel and lots of bourbon. You can definitely taste the Serpents Stout in there as well, which I loved. Palate is great. Smooth, and full-bodied. I definitely enjoyed this one.

375mL. The pour is a tepid, hazy, deep mahogany with a lively, small, deep yellow head. Little retention and lace. Nice, low carbonation for this style. Aroma is very full and rich: heavy buttery bourbon, rich coconut oil, cinnamon, apple butter, old port. Approaching a 9/10 on the nose. Taste is rich, chocolate, butter, hazelnut, Nutella, dark chocolate ganache. Palate is rich, full, sharp, lightly tannic, oily to the extreme. Soft. Mild alcohol warming and slight rich booziness. Really delicious. Reminds me a bit of BA Santas Little Helper with less carbonation and little more alcohol kick. So good- I wish it came in 750s. Cant wait to try some more of this in a couple of months or so. Doesnt really need to cellar that much anymore. This is very much good to go.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown, almost black, with a small fizzy brown head that retained as a thin covering.  The nose is quite dense with a hefty maltiness dueling it out with the barrel character.  Theres a bit more brandy barrel coming thru than bourbon.  Rich vanilla and charred wood with deep burnt caramel and thick roastiness.  The flavor comes across as quite boozy at first sip with thick syrupy malt.  The flavor is definately leaning towards the Angels Share, but the deep roastiness is a nice addition to the mix.  Lots of burnt caramel and heavy dark fruits.  Quite decadent in its intensity.  Full bodied and thickly syrupy with nice slightly fizzy carbonation that helps cut the heaviness well.
