Very small off-white head that fully diminished except for a small ring around the edge.  No lace.  Flavor is very sweet and bitter.  Palate is very full bodied and oily soft.  longer than average and slightly cloying finish.  Overall a very intense brew that showcases the bourbon and brandy upfront.  This does leave everything else in the background and I would have been more impressed if it was a bit more balanced in that respect.  I did enjoy this sipper very much so it is a good decadent brew.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2011 375ml bottle courtesy of freddy at bev4less. Thanks. Pours an opaque black color with a small tan head that soon fades to a fine ring. The nose is rich with molasses, dark fruits, whiskey and mocha. The flavor is complex with layered chocolates, brandy, raisins, dates, roasted malts and sweet molasses. The palate is smooth and malty with lively carbonation. The finish is long and semi-sweet. Overall: One of the finest big ales...ever.

So, in the last couple of weeks I have had this on tap at the brewery and in the bottle.   One thing is certain, this is a boozy beer.   Super hot.  The aroma is so boozy that with the strength of the beer, you almost feel like your drinking a glass of brandy. Carbonation was perfect.  Maybe its just me, but I cant say that there is anything here that particularly stands out.  Kind of reminds me of the BA version of Santas little helper.

375 ml corked and caged bottle poured a clear dark brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of brandy, burnt carmel, raisin, toffee, light oak and light vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of carmel, brandy, toffee, oak, raisin, plum and bourbon with a smooth dry lingering roasty fruity finish.
Almost black. Bourbon, vanilla, raisins, butter toffee, toasted oak aroma.  Creamy mouthfeel. Rich vanilla and bourbon flavors. Smooth and a bit more mellow than I expected. Delicious!

This was a fine beer - I suggest holding on to you bottle for a little bit though if you can.  Pours dark brown with a small head.  Nose of brandy, bourbon, wood, toffee, chocolate, caramel.  It is a little hot still, but a damn fine beer.  Thick and sweet, good caramel, coffee, and booze.  Well done.

A: The pour is black and ominous with a fingers worth of mocha colored foam that eventually settles down to a thin cap.

S: Plenty of vanilla is present immediately along with a nice chocolate notes, of both dark and semisweet varieties, combining nicely with some roast from the Serpents Stout. The two spirits (brandy and bourbon) work together nicely without either really being all that noticeable. A bit of a wood and alcohol note as well.

T: The sweet chocolate flavor (almost cake-like) and vanilla come through wonderfully and are the first things I pick up. The wood, bourbon, and subtle flavors of roasted malts provide a bit of a balance to the sweetness. More sweetness to follow with some caramel and brown sugar.

M: The body is medium to full with a mellow carbonation that provides for a creamy mouthfeel.

D: As I finish entering my notes I realize that Ive probably already had about 12 ounces of this beer. Again, the pint was not entirely necessary for such a beer, but for less than the price of one of the 12 ounce bottles, I wont complain too much.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2014 dark brown near black.  smell amazingly complex vanilla, chocolate, roasted malt, a touch of brandy and ripe fruit.  super duper smooth.  head to head with a 6 month old Angels Share grand cru, and this one is not as hot, although its definitely a sipper.  one of the best sippers actually.  best of both brews.  gotta do a head to head with a regular old serpent stout to determine my favorite lost abbey beer.  wish they were reasonably priced, though.

12.7 oz bottle. Great label art! Opened with a slight (very) pop. Pours with a small bit of carbonation that mostly dissipated quickly.  Solid black. Nose is very boozy with a touch of chocolate. Taste: very  sweet and a bit sticky but not over the top. Alcohol is definitely present all the way through. Its a bit young and I believe this will settle down and be better a few month from now.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Very dark molasses pour with a creamy thin latte head.  This brew has some legs.  Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, raisin, oak, and bourbon.  Flavor is assertive but not aggressive, with a nice balance between the original flavors and the barrel.  Vanilla, dark fruit, wood, cocoa, and bourbon all make their way to the palate.  The alcohol is there but isnt distracting.  Definitely a sipper but a really good one.  Just the right level of carbonation to ignite the palate.

First off, I smelled booze the second I uncorked this one...pour is murky black with a thin sticky tan head...smell is then pretty overwhelming...cocoa, vanilla, wood, booze, alcohol, heat, sweetness...I mean wow...this is certainly barrel aged...and holy shit the sweetness...the first thing I taste is grapeskin and fruit...bitter and sweet...then a hint of chocolate and BAM...alcohol....the brandy comes out in the fruity flavors but bourbon is just overpowering...hot and sweet sweet sweet...there is a lot going on here but none if it is particularly good...this is just all over the place and not really in the good way...finish is lingeringly boozey and sweet...I have to say that this idea sure was a fun experiment to drink, but all of these things going on at the same time was a bit offending to the palate...neat idea none the less...

375ml bottle. Pours deep dark brown with minimal head.  The nose is sweet brandy, toffee, brown sugar, molasses and milk chocolate.  The taste is smoky wood, vanilla, burnt caramel, ashy cocoa, roasted malt, dried dark fruits and light bourbon tones.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel with some prickly carbonation on the tongue.  Theres a lot going on in this beer - very tasty brew for sure.  Warming on the belly but the booze is well hidden in the flavor.

pours opaque murky brown to black with a 3mm creamy, dark brown head. nice lacing, nice legs, spot on carbonation leaves a skim and a ring and an easy swirl re-stirs a nice layer. aroma is quite boozy, especially colder. as it warms lots of raisins and prunes and figs with burnt molasses hit you up front, with a slightly sweeter caramel in the finish from the AS. the taste is very complex and also very well balanced. i am getting both beers coming through strongly and working in perfect harmony. the barrel profile between the two is quite intense and large. i really enjoy it but think that it may be detracting from the true complexity of the mix just a touch. there is sweet, lighter malts of the As and roasty dark malt of the SS, some nice bittering hops and light floral additions from both beers hop profiles. it has a nice sweet oily spirit like quality from the as and a creamy aspect added in from the SS, very nice the body. this is really a great blend, it allows both beers to shine and is just as tasty as either of them on their own, a truly righteous concoction.

Boozy chocolate aroma. Raisin. Plumb. Very rich and intense. Lots of roast here. Some subtle sweetness. I need to try one side by side with Angels Share to see how the blend differs. From memory, it tastes like a better Angels Share. Perfect end of the evening beer.

Pours a thick viscous deep brownish black with a light brown head and a real purty mouth. Aroma is brandy, oak, bourbon, chocolate, caramel, toffee, butterscotch, roast. Flavor is roast, caramel, brandy, oak, tannins, bourbon, spices, molasses, brown sugar, chocolate. Tiny effervescent carbonation bubbles battle their way through the viscous body of the beer bring out nuances of this blend at the tip of your tongue, especially the barrel, oaky tannins, bourbon and brandy while the caramel and butterscotch sweetness melds in harmony with the booze in the back of your tongue. This is a great blend.

On tap at the brewery.  Thick, opaque black, and very viscous with a very thin dark brown head.  Strong, boozey aroma with dark roast, deep caramel, vanilla, and toffee.  The booze comes through quite assertively in the flavor as well, but is intermingled with dark malt, alcohol, barrel oxidation, and some nicely integrated sweetness.  It all comes together very well in the body.  Make no mistake: this is a big beer with huge alcohol and malt.  But thats the point.  And this beer pulls off just such an M.O.  better than most.  This is classy stuff that will certainly only improve with age.

On tap at Deliverance release. Pours a rich dark brown with small tan head. Aromas of bourbon and rich dark malts, a hint of smokiness. Mouth feel is thick with moderate carbonation. Flavors of dark fruits, some oak. Finishes a little hot, great beer however may taste better once it settles out a bit.

A full pint enjoyed at the brewery ($8).  Pours black with a thin layer of brown foam.  Aroma is mellow with lots of woody barrel notes -- bourbon and brandy...check; also vanilla, chocolate, and marshmallows.  Flavor is surprisingly ultra-smooth and also complex with notes of silky rich chocolate, marshmallows, vanilaa, oak, sweet-boozy, bourbon, and molasses.  Good carbonation...an unfortunate concern with Lost Abbey these days but this is nicely carbonated.  It is on the sweet side but pleasant and far from cloying.  This is sufficiently different from both the Angels Share and Serpents Stout as to completely stand on its own...sure I could try to pick out the elements of the component beers but that would take away from the pure pleasure of this fantastic blend.  Really great stuff...Im loving the complexity of these dark Lost Abbey beers.  (11, 370)

Draft at the brewery.  Thick black pour, short dense tan head.  Chocolate, dark fruit, oak, lots of vanilla, bourbon, brandy, molasses, and toffee.  This was thick and chewy, mostly sweet malts.  Very good.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2010 On tap at the Release. Pours with a near black body with a huge lasting tan head. Big woody, chewy nose: burnt, toffee, vinous, and very rich. Molasses. Taste is rich, very rich, burnt, alcohol, brandy, bourbon, chewy goodness, vanilla, wood. Lively bubbles. Thick. Wrong weather, but great beer!

On draft at Lost Abbey for Pre-Stone 14th anniversary breakfast. Poured a cola brown with no head. Aroma was bourbon, grass, and oak. Taste was bourbon, chocolate, raisins. Medium carbonation. Overall very good. Easier to drink than angel share alone!

Tasted at the Stone Anny fest. Dark brown black hues with minimal tan top. Roasty malty aromas. Medium full body. What a fantastic blend and combo of these two beers. The coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and molasses of Serpents intertwine perfectly with the bourbon, heat, and caramel of Angels. Great complexity of flavors obviously. Finish is long lasting sweet and very tasty. Great beer!!

Draft at Stone 14th. A total hybrid of the two constituent beers, the Serpent Stout is apparent on the initial mouthfeel and roasty malt character, but the Angels Share takes over with a boozey, dark fruit, caramel profile that lingers into the sweet and warming finish with woody tones throughout, great blend!

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2011 Served (on tap I think) at the Stone 14th Anniversary Celebration. The appearance is a cola brown without a lot of head. The flavors and aromas are brandy, raisin, spicy oak, vanilla, heavy roasted flavors. A really good beer that will be even better with some time on it.

Served out of the bottle with about a year on it (batch 1). The appearance is a deep midnight black with a small brown head. Dried dark fruits, barrel, Flavors of raisins, dates, booze, brandy barrel, chard oak, some peppery spice, vanilla. Very boozy, this hasnt changed much from what I remember of the first time.

On tap at source, #4! 
Appearance:  Pours a viscous dark brown with a faint oily swirl on top.

Aroma: Big bourbon sweetness and some bourbon soaked dark fruit.

Taste: Burnt roast, char,caramel, warm alcohol, coffee, with some spicy hops at the tail end of the sip. The flavor lingers well past the sip.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, prickly pronounced carbonation.

Overall:  Simply amazing. The burnt roast notes balance out the bourbon/Angel Share goodness into one of the most solid balanced bourbon barrel aged strong ales Ive had.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2010 8/21/10 - Free sample after squealing like a pig at the brewery.  Thick and heavy on the angels share with vanilla, date, and slight spice.  Definite sipper.  Minimal bourbon and a nice chocolate/cocoa dryness at the end of the finish.  Heavy but not overwhelming and definitely not overly sweet nor syrupy.  Somewhat creamy in the middle.  Great beer and Im quite curious to see how it tastes a few years from now.

9/11/10 - rerate from a bottle.  I get a little more bourbon on the nose but it mostly strikes me as AS.  More fresh bourbon in the taste than I recall from on tap.  Some raisin, wet chocolate, and sharp alcohol in the finish.  Preferred it more on tap. (-.1 on the palate and taste each).

Sample at Lost Abbey brunch. Rating# 2. Super dark brown with a nice chocolate head. Aroma is rich dark fruits, raisins, molasses and some chocolate. Flavor is bourbon, chocolate and a nice roasty bite, really good stuff. (1355)
